title: Multi-Partition Embedding Interaction with Block Term Format for Knowledge Graph Completion

sections.experimental settings:
We use four popular benchmark datasets for link prediction, as shown in Table 1. WN18  and WN18RR [ref]7 are subsets of WordNet 8, which contains lexical relationships between words. FB15K  and FB15K-237 4 are subsets of Freebase , which contains general facts. WN18 and FB15K are more popular, whereas WN18RR and FB15K-237 are recently built and more competitive.

 We evaluate and analyze MEI on the link prediction task . In this task, for each true triple (h,t,r)â„ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿ(h,t,r) in the test set, we replace hâ„h and tğ‘¡t by every other entity to generate corrupted triples (hâ€²,t,r)superscriptâ„â€²ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿ(h^{\prime},t,r) and (h,tâ€²,r)â„superscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘Ÿ(h,t^{\prime},r), respectively. The goal of the model is to rank the true triple (h,t,r)â„ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿ(h,t,r) before the corrupted triples based on the score ğ’®ğ’®{\mathcal{S}}. We compute popular evaluation metrics including Mâ€‹Râ€‹Rğ‘€ğ‘…ğ‘…MRR (mean reciprocal rank, which is robust to outlier rankings) and Hâ€‹@â€‹kğ»@ğ‘˜H@k for kâˆˆ{1,3,10}ğ‘˜1310k\in\{1,3,10\} (Hits at kğ‘˜k, which is how many true triples are correctly ranked in the top kğ‘˜k) . The higher Mâ€‹Râ€‹Rğ‘€ğ‘…ğ‘…MRR and Hâ€‹@â€‹kğ»@ğ‘˜H@k are, the better the model performs. To avoid false-negative error, i.e., some corrupted triples are actually existent, we follow the protocols used in other works for filtered metrics . In this protocol, all existent triples in the training, validation, and test sets are removed from the corrupted triples set before computing the rank of the true triple. To evaluate the prediction on the optimal parameter efficiency, we compare MEI1Ã—200 (vanilla Tucker model) and MEI3Ã—100. The aim is to show that the model with optimal parameter efficiency can achieve better results with even fewer parameters. We also evaluate MEI against several strong baselines including classic models such as TransE, RESCAL, DistMult, and recent state-of-the-art models such as ComplEx, SimplE, and ConvE. We also compare MEI with TorusE that uses larger embedding size; ComplEx at K=400ğ¾400K=400 that was retuned with N3 weight decay, reciprocal relation, and full softmax loss; and RotatE without the adversarial sampling technique as this technique is not subjected to a specific model. We trained MEI using mini-batch stochastic gradient descent with Adam optimizer . We followed the 1-N scoring procedure in [ref]7 for negative sampling of (h,t,r)â„ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿ(h,t,r), where negative samples are reused multiple times for computation efficiency and the number of negative samples is different for each triple. The results of MEI1Ã—200 are reproduced from the vanilla Tucker model in ; note that the relation embedding size Dr=30subscriptğ·ğ‘Ÿ30D_{r}=30 on WN18 and WN18RR only. All hyperparameters of MEI3Ã—100 are tuned by random search , including batch size, learning rate, decay rate, batch normalization, and dropout rates, which we will publish together with the code. Note that in these experiments, we restrict them to the simplified case of one single shared-core tensor for all Kğ¾K partitions, as an analogy to single interaction patterns in previous specially designed models.
